awd_titl_txt: Cognitive Diagnosis Models: Identifiability, Estimation, and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Cognitive diagnosis models (CDMs) are state-of-the-art psychometric models in education, psychology, and other social sciences. This research project will introduce a comprehensive theoretical and methodological framework that will make construction and analysis of CDM-based assessments more practicable. This development will provide a better understanding of the skills and cognitive processes involved in cognitive assessments. From a societal perspective, the integration of CDMs with cognitive and learning sciences will provide a powerful tool for identifying specific problems and difficulties that students encounter in skill acquisition. This interdisciplinary research project will help design a blueprint for mapping out timely, appropriate, and targeted interventions. The results of this project have the potential to positively impact STEM education and the training of students. Graduate students will be involved in the conduct of the research. Publicly available software also will be developed.

This research project addresses fundamental identifiability and estimation issues of CDMs. Specifically, the project will address identifiability issues for general CDMs and provide practical guidelines for designing identifiable and statistical valid diagnosis tests. The project will address the challenging issue of Q-matrix validation and estimation. The research will develop computationally efficient methods to estimate the Q-matrix and detect possible misspecification of the Q-matrix and provide the related theoretical justification. The project also will develop an accessible computer program that can be used in conjunction with the proposed theory and methods. Extensive simulation studies will be performed to validate the performance of the estimation methods, and a variety of real data sets will be analyzed.

por.por_cntn:
This research project contributes to developing both fundamental statistical theory and efficient computational methodology for cognitive diagnosis models (CDMs), which are a family of discrete latent variable models widely employed in educational, psychological, social, and biological applications. CDMs offers a general framework to achieve fine-grained inference on individuals' latent attributes, based on their observed multivariate responses, and also to obtain the latent subgroups of a population, based on the inferred attribute patterns. In practice, each latent attribute is often assumed to be binary and has particular scientific interpretations, such as mastery or deficiency of some targeted skill in educational assessment, presence or absence of some underlying mental disorder in psychiatric diagnosis, existence or nonexistence of some disease pathogen in the medical diagnosis of disease etiology. In these applications, the framework of CDMs enables one to simultaneously achieve the statistical learning task of clustering and the scientific purpose of diagnostic inference.

Despite their popularity, CDMs often suffer from the non-identifiability issue as many other latent structure models. Identifiability is a crucial prerequisite for consistent estimation and valid inference. The identifiability problem of CDMs in Cognitive Diagnosis is very challenging and has long been a concern since the birth of CDMs in the 1980s. To address this challenge, this project has established sufficient and necessary conditions for the identifiability and estimability of the CDMs as well as the latent structure Q-matrix. The PI has also established the consistent estimation theory for CDMs. The new statistical tools to prove the identifiability and consistency results are not only applicable to the general family of restricted latent class models, including the popularly used cognitive diagnosis models such as DINA, DINO, ACDM, R-RUM, GDINA, LCDM, and GDM, but also applicable to other complicated latent attribute models in the statistics and machine learning literature.

In addition, this project has addressed another major challenge in CDMs that concerns with the misspecification of the structural Q-matrix. One major issue in practice is that the Q-matrix often suffers from potential misspecification by domain experts in confirmatory-type applications, or even entirely unknown in exploratory-type applications. This project has developed consistency theory, estimation algorithms, and inference tools for the CDMs with their applications in educational and psychological assessments.

The research results have been disseminated to communities of interest. This project has led to 20 publications in top statistics and psychometrics journals, such as the Annals of Statistics, Journal of the American Statistical Association, Biometrika, Journal of Machine Learning Research, Biometrics, Psychometrika, and British Journal of Mathematical and Statistical Psychology. There are also currently 9 manuscripts under revision or review in top journals. The PI and his students have presented the research results in several major statistical conferences and seminars. The developed software codes have been distributed to several research groups who have shown interest in the research and requested it, and the codes are also shared publically online at Github.

In addition to the research activities, the PI has also been actively involved in mentoring and training students. (1) The PI has been mentoring (or mentored) 7 Ph.D. students. Particularly, the PI has two Ph.D. students who successfully graduated in 2020. One of them, Yuqi Gu, successfully defended her thesis in March 2020 and will join the Statistics Department at Columbia University as a tenure-track Assistant Professor in 2021. His graduate students have received various awards and recognitions, such as the Rackham Predoctoral Fellowship, Institute of Mathematical Statistics (IMS) Lawrence D. Brown Ph.D. Student Award, IMS Hannan Graduate Student Travel Award, and Joint Statistical Meeting Biometrics Section Travel Award. (2) The PI has supervised four undergraduate students for research activities at the University of Michigan since 2017. Three of them did their Honors Thesis on cognitive diagnosis modeling under the PI's supervision. In particular, Ms. Song received the Outstanding Undergraduate Major Award from the Statistics Department in 2019 and presented her research at the undergraduate graduation ceremony. 

The PI has also received awards from professional statistical societies, thanks to the support of this grant on his research activities. Particularly, he received the Outstanding Young Researcher Award (2019) from the International Chinese Statistical Association "for his fundamental contributions to latent-class models and statistical modeling and inference for educational measurements." He also received the Bernoulli Society New Researcher Award (2019) and delivered an invited talk at the 62nd World Statistics Congress.

The findings and outcomes of this project provide a comprehensive theoretical and methodological framework that makes the design and analysis of CDM-based assessments more practicable. They also contribute to advancement in other disciplines, such as cognitive and learning sciences, to provide a better understanding of the cognitive diagnostic skills involved in cognitive assessments. More broadly, the integration of cognitive diagnosis with educational learning sciences can provide a useful tool in identifying specific challenges and difficulties that students encounter in STEM education.
